case_studies.title: Weimar Republic Hyperinflation (1921–1923)
case_studies.summary: Germany printed money to pay war reparations, destroying the mark. By November 1923, 1 USD = 4.2 trillion marks. Citizens burned currency for warmth.

case_studies.title: Japan's Lost Decade (1991–2001)
case_studies.summary: After a real estate and equity bubble, Japan's Nikkei fell 60%. GDP growth averaged 1.1% for 10 years. Zero interest rate policy failed to revive demand.

case_studies.title: Argentina Debt Default (2001)
case_studies.summary: After pegging the peso to the USD, Argentina ran unsustainable deficits. GDP contracted 11% in 2002. Unemployment hit 25%. Over $100B in sovereign debt defaulted.

case_studies.title: Global Financial Crisis (2008)
case_studies.summary: Mortgage-backed securities with hidden subprime exposure caused Lehman Brothers to collapse. $11 trillion in household wealth was wiped out in the US alone.

case_studies.title: Dot-Com Bubble (1999–2001)
case_studies.summary: NASDAQ rose 400% then fell 78%. Companies with no revenue traded at 100x sales. $5 trillion in market cap evaporated between 2000–2002.

case_studies.title: Turkish Lira Crisis (2018–2021)
case_studies.summary: Erdogan pressured the central bank to cut rates during inflation. The lira lost 80% against the USD between 2018–2021. Inflation hit 85% in 2022.

case_studies.title: Evergrande Collapse (2021)
case_studies.summary: China's second-largest property developer held $300B in liabilities. Its collapse threatened 40% of China's GDP tied to real estate. Beijing refused a full bailout.

case_studies.title: Silicon Valley Bank Failure (2023)
case_studies.summary: SVB held long-duration bonds in a rising rate environment. When rates surged, bond values collapsed. A $1.8B loss disclosure triggered a $42B bank run in 48 hours.

case_studies.title: Saudi Aramco IPO (2019)
case_studies.summary: The world's largest IPO at $25.6B. Aramco's profits of $161B in 2022 dwarfed all Western oil majors combined. A case study in state-controlled resource monetization.

case_studies.title: Berkshire Hathaway's Cash Discipline (2023)
case_studies.summary: Buffett held $147B in cash when markets were richly valued. This 'dry powder' strategy allowed selective deployment during dislocations — patience as a return strategy.

case_studies.title: Fed's 2022 Rate Hike Cycle
case_studies.summary: The fastest tightening since 1981: 525bps in 18 months. US 10-year Treasury went from 1.5% to 5%. Caused $18 trillion in global bond losses — the worst fixed income drawdown in history.

case_studies.title: Tesla Short Sellers (2019–2021)
case_studies.summary: Bears lost $38B in 2020 alone as Tesla rose 740%. The company was unprofitable for years but commanded a $1.2T valuation at peak. A case study in narrative vs fundamentals.

case_studies.title: Norway Government Pension Fund
case_studies.summary: The world's largest sovereign wealth fund at $1.6T, funded by oil revenues. Owns 1.5% of all global listed equities. A model of intergenerational wealth preservation.

case_studies.title: SoftBank Vision Fund Losses (2022)
case_studies.summary: SoftBank's $100B Vision Fund lost $27B in a single fiscal year. Over-concentration in unprofitable tech at peak valuations. A master class in leverage risk.

case_studies.title: Zimbabwe Hyperinflation (2007–2009)
case_studies.summary: Inflation reached 89.7 sextillion percent per month. The government printed $100 trillion notes. Citizens transacted in USD and foreign goods. Currency was eventually abandoned.

quotes.quote: He who lives by the crystal ball will eat shattered glass.
quotes.context: Dalio said this when discussing probabilistic thinking vs prediction in managing Bridgewater's All Weather Portfolio.
quotes.principle: Stress-test scenarios rather than forecasting single outcomes. Position for multiple futures simultaneously.

quotes.quote: Price is what you pay. Value is what you get.
quotes.context: Buffett wrote this distinguishing the market price of an asset from its intrinsic economic value during a period of irrational exuberance.
quotes.principle: Separate the market's opinion of an asset from the cash flows it will generate. Buy the gap between the two.

quotes.quote: I never use valuation to time the market. I use liquidity.
quotes.context: Druckenmiller explained why he rode the 1990s tech bubble far longer than value investors — he tracked Fed liquidity, not P/E ratios.
quotes.principle: Central bank money flows move markets more than fundamentals in the short term. Follow the liquidity tide.

quotes.quote: The most important rule of trading is to play great defense, not great offense.
quotes.context: Tudor Jones said this explaining why he obsessively cuts losers fast — he survived the 1987 crash by having asymmetric risk controls in place.
quotes.principle: Capital preservation precedes capital growth. The math of loss recovery (need 100% gain to recover 50% loss) makes defense structurally superior.

quotes.quote: It's not whether you're right or wrong that's important, but how much money you make when you're right and how much you lose when you're wrong.
quotes.context: Soros described this as the core of reflexivity — his framework for why payoff asymmetry matters more than win rate.
quotes.principle: A 40% win rate with 3:1 reward-to-risk beats an 80% win rate with 1:1. Focus on bet sizing and exits, not accuracy.

quotes.quote: Invert, always invert. Turn a situation or problem upside down. Look at it backwards.
quotes.context: Munger applied this to avoiding financial ruin — instead of asking how to get rich, ask what destroys wealth and eliminate those behaviors.
quotes.principle: Risk management by subtraction. Remove the ways you lose first, and outperformance becomes more probable.

quotes.quote: You can't predict. You can prepare.
quotes.context: Marks wrote this memo after Lehman collapsed, explaining why Oaktree was positioned in distressed debt before the crisis — through scenario preparation, not forecasting.
quotes.principle: Build portfolios robust to multiple outcomes. Preparation compounds. Prediction fails.

quotes.quote: The person that turns over the most rocks wins the game.
quotes.context: Lynch described his investment process at Fidelity Magellan — visiting companies, reading filings, talking to competitors — generating 29.2% annual returns for 13 years.
quotes.principle: Information edge comes from depth of research, not speed of reaction. Do the work others won't.

quotes.quote: We should never assume the world will be safer tomorrow than it is today.
quotes.context: Dimon wrote this justifying JPMorgan holding excess capital buffers above regulatory minimums — a decision that cost short-term ROE but protected through 2008 and 2020.
quotes.principle: Stress-testing for tail risks isn't pessimism — it's the structural advantage of surviving when competitors don't.

quotes.quote: We are willing to be misunderstood for long periods of time.
quotes.context: Bezos wrote this explaining Amazon's decision to sacrifice near-term profits for market share — a strategy Wall Street punished for years before it compounded into $1.3T in value.
quotes.principle: Long-duration thinking requires accepting short-term misalignment with consensus. Conviction must be backed by data, not sentiment.
